qas.question: What year was the Jenkins Orphanage created?
What Charleston Reverend established the Jenkins Orphanage?
What type of donations did the Jerkins Orphanage accept?
Whose graduates tutored many boys from the Jenkins Orphanage?
What city was Louis Armstrong from?
What year was the Jenkins Orphanage closed?
What Charleston Reverend closed the Jenkins Orphanage?
What type of donations did the Jerkins Orphanage reject?
Whose graduates tutored many girls from the Jenkins Orphanage?
What city wasn't Louis Armstrong from?

context: The Jenkins Orphanage was established in <a0_0><b5_0>1891<b5_0/><a0_0/> by the Rev. <a1_0><b6_0>Daniel J. Jenkins<b6_0/><a1_0/> in Charleston. The orphanage accepted <a2_0><b7_0>donations of musical instruments<b7_0/><a2_0/> and Rev. Jenkins hired local Charleston musicians and <a3_0><b8_0>Avery Institute Graduates<b8_0/><a3_0/> to tutor the boys in music. As a result, Charleston musicians became proficient on a variety of instruments and were able to read music expertly. These traits set Jenkins musicians apart and helped land some of them positions in big bands with Duke Ellington and Count Basie. William "Cat" Anderson, Jabbo Smith, and Freddie Green are but a few of the alumni from the Jenkins Orphanage band who became professional musicians in some of the best bands of the day. Orphanages around the country began to develop brass bands in the wake of the Jenkins Orphanage Band's success. At the Colored Waif's Home Brass Band in <a4_0><b9_0>New Orleans<b9_0/><a4_0/>, for example, a young trumpeter named Louis Armstrong first began to draw attention.
